awd_titl_txt: University of Minnesota/RV Blue Heron 2023 Shipboard Scientific Support Equipment
awd_abstract_narration:
A request is made to fund additional and back-up science support equipment for the R/V Blue Heron, an 86-foot Coastal research vessel owned by the University of Minnesota and operated by the Large Lakes Observatory as part of the US Academic Research Fleet (ARF). Built in 1985 for fishing on the Grand Banks, the Blue Heron was purchased by the University of Minnesota in 1997. The vessel is outfitted with state-of-the-art research equipment, has berthing for 11 crew and scientists, and can operate 24 hours per day for up to 21 days in between port calls. The Blue Heron is part of the University National Oceanographic Laboratory System (UNOLS), and is available for charter by research scientists on any of the Great Lakes. In 2022, the vessel completed 110 funded days, 45 of these (41%) were for NSF. In 2023, the vessel is scheduled for 55 days, 36 of which (65%) will be for NSF.

Shipboard Scientific Support Equipment (SSSE) requested in this proposal includes:

1)	Navigational suite upgrade	$20,542	
2)	Work boat	$22,422	
							$42,964	
Broader Impacts
The principal impact of the present proposal is under Merit Review Criterion 2 of the Proposal Guidelines (NSF 19-602). It provides infrastructure support for scientists to use the vessel and its shared-use instrumentation in support of their NSF-funded oceanographic research projects (which individually undergo separate review by the relevant research program of NSF).  The acquisition, maintenance and operation of shared-use instrumentation allows NSF-funded researchers from any US university or lab access to working, calibrated instruments for their research, reducing the cost of that research, and expanding the base of potential researchers.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF MINNESOTA

por.por_cntn:
The RV Blue Heron is a research vessel owned and operated by the University of Minnesota that assists researchers and educators in their work on all of the North American Great Lakes.  The University of Minnesota purchased an autopilot and satellite compass for the RV Blue Heron’s navigational system, a workboat for the vessel’s shallow water operations, and upgraded the ship’s McLane in-situ water sampling instrument using funds provided by National Science Foundation award OCE#2313789 ‘SSSE 2023 UMD R/V Blue Heron Shipboard Scientific Support Equipment’.  The autopilot, satellite compass, workboat, and in-situ water sampler will allow the vessel to better serve the researchers and educators who use the vessel.

 

RV Blue Heron’s navigational equipment was becoming aged and was no longer manufactured or serviced by the manufacturer and this grant allowed us to replace this very important gear that is necessary for the safe operation of the vessel.  Additionally, our rigid hull inflatable workboat was over 20 years old and needed continuous maintenance.  This grant allowed us to replace the workboat with a new workboat. Finally, one of our in-situ pumps, an instrument that we lower into the water and program it to filter large volumes of lake water past filters which are analyzed later by scientists, was damaged and funds from this grant allowed us to upgrade and refurbish the pump.

 

The new equipment is available to all users of R/V Blue Heron, including the National Science Foundation funded project that is using the vessel in 2025.  Besides the NSF funded project, we are supporting several other science projects in 2025: a cruise funded by the Legislative-Citizens Commission on Minnesota Resources, several Sea Grant cruises, a State of Minnesota Department of Natural Resources cruise, a cruise funded by National Sciences and Engineering Research Council of Canada, and multiple research and educational cruises funded by the University of Minnesota.  Regarding the educational cruises, the University of Minnesota is funding eight cruises in 2025 which will expose close to 200 undergraduates to scientific research on the Great Lakes.

 


Last Modified: 04/08/2025
Modified by: Richard D Ricketts
por.por_txt_cntn:
The RV Blue Heron is a research vessel owned and operated by the University of Minnesota that assists researchers and educators in their work on all of the North American Great Lakes. The University of Minnesota purchased an autopilot and satellite compass for the RV Blue Herons navigational system, a workboat for the vessels shallow water operations, and upgraded the ships McLane in-situ water sampling instrument using funds provided by National Science Foundation award OCE#2313789 SSSE 2023 UMD R/V Blue Heron Shipboard Scientific Support Equipment. The autopilot, satellite compass, workboat, and in-situ water sampler will allow the vessel to better serve the researchers and educators who use the vessel.





RV Blue Herons navigational equipment was becoming aged and was no longer manufactured or serviced by the manufacturer and this grant allowed us to replace this very important gear that is necessary for the safe operation of the vessel. Additionally, our rigid hull inflatable workboat was over 20 years old and needed continuous maintenance. This grant allowed us to replace the workboat with a new workboat. Finally, one of our in-situ pumps, an instrument that we lower into the water and program it to filter large volumes of lake water past filters which are analyzed later by scientists, was damaged and funds from this grant allowed us to upgrade and refurbish the pump.





The new equipment is available to all users of R/V Blue Heron, including the National Science Foundation funded project that is using the vessel in 2025. Besides the NSF funded project, we are supporting several other science projects in 2025: a cruise funded by the Legislative-Citizens Commission on Minnesota Resources, several Sea Grant cruises, a State of Minnesota Department of Natural Resources cruise, a cruise funded by National Sciences and Engineering Research Council of Canada, and multiple research and educational cruises funded by the University of Minnesota. Regarding the educational cruises, the University of Minnesota is funding eight cruises in 2025 which will expose close to 200 undergraduates to scientific research on the Great Lakes.
